posts.cooked:

posts.name: Ari Meles-Braverman
posts.cooked:
What did you use solid profiles instead of hollow tubes?

For real though, the answer is ‚Äúas light as possible and no lighter‚Äù. If I had to give a number, I‚Äôd say for us that usually comes out around 30 kg.

posts.name: Eren Orhun
posts.cooked: They were hollow, but i gave offset to wrong side while making the tubes. Still, they are pretty heavy.

posts.name: Stewart Riley
posts.cooked: You‚Äôre using 80mm square tubes? That‚Äôs excessive for anything like a robot cart, those are pretty much structural tubes for holding up serious weight (like, several hundred kg.) Make the cart out of more standard tube, something on the order of 50mm x 25mm or even 25mm square, with a wall thickness of 2mm or 3mm (the rough equivalent of SAE 2" x 1" tube or 1" x 1" tube with .062 or .125 wall thickness.) You overbuilt this thing so much that it‚Äôs no wonder that it‚Äôs heavy.

posts.name: 829 The Digital Goats Official Curmudgeon.
posts.cooked: 40" wide is way too big and wont fit through most doors. Most carts are 24-30" max. I would lean to the shorter side like 600mm.

posts.name: chrisrin
posts.cooked:
AriMB:

‚Äúas light as possible and no lighter‚Äù

+1 I would not rule out alternative materials like baltic birch plywood that can enable a solution that is more than strong enough and quite light weight.

posts.name: JRumple
posts.cooked:
I recommend going back and defining the problem better. I don‚Äôt recommend focusing on a measure of the solution. Make sure you‚Äôve defined the right problem.

Every team will have different resources, constraints, and operational uses.

As one person mentioned, 40‚Äù will be too wide for many doors. ADA codes require a 32‚Äù door. If you need to transport your robot to outreach events on the cart, then fitting in an ADA compliant 32‚Äù door needs to be considered.

Some teams have trailers with ramps and they can wheel their robot cart on and off the trailer. Other teams must load their robot, cart, and pit equipment under their bus. This requires a very different style cart.

Some venues have wide aisle ways and broad corners. Other venues have narrow doors and require zero radius turns. Some venues have a ramp between the pit area and the competition area where a too heavy cart could go out of control and injure someone.

Instead of defining a ‚Äúright‚Äù cart weight, I recommend getting back into the problem definition and studying how the cart will be used and what its purpose is. Writing down a Concept of Operations (CONOPS) and developing User Stories or Use Cases will help you separate the problem from the solution.

posts.name: Chris Gerth
posts.cooked:
To literally answer the thread title, I want a cart that is exactly zero pounds. No more, no less.

However, if I can‚Äôt get exactly zero, cart with slight negative weight is far worse than a cart with slight positive weight.

posts.name: usbcd36
Troy Dietz
posts.cooked:
One person should be able to lift the entire cart in a pinch. Doesn‚Äôt have to be easy, but if it‚Äôs over ~100 lbs, something is wrong. Especially if the isn‚Äôt storage for toolboxes and batteries and snacks and water bottles and the armoire.

gerthworm:

To literally answer the thread title, I want a cart that is exactly zero pounds. No more, no less.

There‚Äôs a JVN blog post (in the internet black hole now) featuring a hilarious exchange as they slowly realize I‚Äôm using the robot like a kick scooter instead of getting the cart.

Maybe don‚Äôt go that far, but consider integrating a shopping cart handle into your robots.

posts.name: EricH
posts.cooked:
Something that hasn‚Äôt been brought up yet: small carts are likely to have field access this year (unless they‚Äôre unsafe). I‚Äôd have to find the blog post for exact size limits. But a small light cart that can hold a robot may be worth looking into.

My cart requirements, no particular order: -single person to move -hold varying 150lb robots over the years -carry some selection of tools and at  least one spare battery -easy to transport, either in one piece or by quick disassembly

Optional: include dedicated spot for driver station (becomes mandatory if driver station is unwieldy) Optional: be under field fit size.

posts.name: Gus Michel II
posts.cooked:
I went exactly where @gerthworm did.  The ideal robot cart would be made out of that infinitely rigid massless stuff in all the high school and freshman physics textbook problems.  Really ideally, it should instantly fold up into something small enough to put in your pocket, like Jane Jetson‚Äôs ‚Äúcar‚Äù.  Just big enough so you don‚Äôt lose it.

More seriously, treat this like any engineering challenge (like your robot, hopefully!).  Define and prioritize your requirements.  Examples might include (in rough order from near certain to far less so):

Carry the Robot

Be small enough to get on the field with the new rules, or at least small enough to fit through doors and into the pit with the robot on it.

Carry the driver station

Carry a spare battery (or two)

Carry a (hopefully small) set of important tools

Be budget friendly (includes both money and time/energy).

Carry paperwork (e.g. checklists, match schedules, strategy sheets)

Be easy to ‚Äútuck away‚Äù fieldside and in the pits, or to double as a workbench or some other function.

Display team colors theme, logos, sponsors, etc.

Once you have your requirements and priorities in order, come up with a few basic designs.  Pick the one that best meets your prioritized requirements, go forth, do more detailed design, build (or buy, sometimes a COTS item is the best answer), and iterate as needed.

posts.name: E L
posts.cooked: our robot cart is super heavy to move simply because we have 2 giant wagon tires in the rear that rarely get inflated, so it feels like you are moving a boulder up a hill all the time during a comp this is just me and team bias but I‚Äôd maybe consider making the bottom a flatter surface and adding a jack to raise and lower the robot platform, it may reduce weight depending on how you build both sides

posts.name: Niels van der Heijden
posts.cooked: The weight of our last made robot cart from 2023 is 22kg and is made  of 30x50x2mm aluminum tube and 10mm plywood. As mentioned earlier, I would advise first look at your requirements and wishes. And I think it makes life a lot easier if it‚Äôs less wide. You can always take a look at our blog post and if you have any questions, I am there to answer them.

posts.name: Ankur Raghavan
posts.cooked:
We‚Äôve used a pneumatic lifting cart for quite a few years now. It‚Äôs small enough to easily fit through a doorway and can easily hold our robot. The lifting capability is really nice and allows the people moving the robot to not need to raise the robot too high. We can then lift the entire platform and work on the robot.

The only problem is it weighs about 90 pounds. This hasn‚Äôt actually been an issue, besides some slight inconveniences and not being able to ship it to Houston.

Size matters much more than weight.
